headline: Butternut and Acorn Squash Soup
description: This is a rich and sweet yet surprisingly simple soup that is wonderful served hot with crusty bread or cold with a dollop of sour cream.
name: Butternut and Acorn Squash Soup

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Place the squash halves cut side down in a baking dish. Bake 45 minutes, or until tender. Remove from heat, and cool slightly. Scoop the pulp from the skins. Discard skins.
Melt the butter in a skillet over medium heat, and saute the onion until tender.
In a blender or food processor, blend the squash pulp, onion, broth, brown sugar, cream cheese, pepper, and cinnamon until smooth. This may be done in several batches.
Transfer the soup to a pot over medium heat, and cook, stirring occasionally, until heated through. Garnish with parsley, and serve warm.

review.reviewBody: So simple. My family begs for it.
The best butternut squash soup I've ever had. Thank you for this recipe!
I completely omitted the cream cheese and used a granny smith apple for some sweetness instead of the brown sugar. It's not as rich but still very good.

I make this every fall. My family loves it, and so do I. We put a little sour cream, crumbled bacon and scallions on top, and serve it with buttered french bread. Oh man is that delicious! Whoever shared this recipe, we all thank you.
Delicious

Oh my gosh! This is so very delicious & not that hard or time-consuming to make! A girlfriend of mine shared the soup & recipe with me & I finally made it with farm-fresh squash. I did add 1 whole Sweet Onion & a package of Neufchâtel (light) Cream Cheese. Only one problem - I wish I had made a double batch right away to put some in the freezer!

I love this recipe. It is easy to make and it freezes well. This time I added some roasted sweet potatoes. I kept everything from the original version except for the cream cheese. It is great for the cold days we have been having
Excellent, rich- tasting soup! Reduced brown sugar to 1 Tbl. I want to try making the same cream base and using broccoli or stewed tomatoes as the vegetable.
This is AMAZING good!!!! Everybody like it. I made no recipe adjustments, its perfect as is!
So good. Added a deseeded chopped jalapeño for a little sweet ‘n spicy action. Was not disappointed. Will definitely make again.

I made it as written except..... added 1/4 tsp ginger and 1/4 tsp cumin, cut the sugar in half and used 2/3 block of cream cheese as suggested by other reviewers. Awesome recipe, serving it on Thanksgiving.

I took the advice of others and did 2/3 the cream cheese block and roughly 1/3 cup of brown sugar, it was still a perfect mix of sweet/savory with these ratios. additionally, I added a few seasonings just for our tastes (chili and cayenne pepper) and it was so so good! will be saving this for thanksgiving this year!
It was really good, but a little too sweet so next time I would use half the brown sugar.

Turned out with just the right creaminess when I used Heavy Cream instead of cream cheese. Also used half the brown sugar. I roasted the butternut squash seeds too! They made a nice crunchy topping. I think I’ll try a dash of smoked paprika and cayenne on top for that great next day serving!

I used a bit more squash. A scant 4 cups. Followed others recommendations and used only 3 teaspoons of brown sugar and 2/3 of the brick of cream cheese. It came out absolutely delicious! The toasted Pepita seeds topping it off.
Delicious as is. Not too sweet especially if you aren’t a squash fan. Family loved it, will make again.
This soup was so good! I used two acorn squash instead of the butternut (I didn't have one) and it was sill delicious. I thought it would be a little thicker but it was still delicious!
Delicious and easy! I substituted the sugar with an apple and it was perfectly sweet.
delicious recipe. However I only added 1 tbsp of brown sugar as squash is already sweet. And used heavy cream instead of cream cheese.
Maybe a dash of salt and pepper.
Excellent. This is a smooth and rich soup that is easy to make and packed with Fall flavors. It’s on the sweet side, but that all comes from the squash...no sugars added. Really tasty!
Warm, savory sweet and velvety smooth! It is a delicious and filling soup.
Restaurant quality soup!

I didn't have butternut squash so used a small can of organic pumpkin. Instead of onions in butter I used onion powder. I added ground cloves. I think I will cut down the sugar, broth and cream cheese. I would like it a little thicker and not as sweet. This is my first time ever making anything with acorn squash. It is delicious and I will make it again!
I added maple bacon to it when I made it. I precooked the bacon and tossed it in the blinder that way it wouldn’t be like eating bacon bits in the soup. Everyone loved it.

Delicious! I used 1/4 cup dark brown sugar, 1/4 cup cream cheese, a little cayenne pepper, and a little salt in addition to all of the other ingredients. After the squash baked, I threw all the ingredients in a pot and used my immersion blender. It was perfect!
Tasty & satisfying! A real hit with my wife!!!

I love creaminess, so I used the whole block of cream cheese -- but that was a little too much even for me, so I'll use 6 oz. next time. One note: don't salt this until it's in the pot warming up. If you use commercially prepared broth, along with the cream cheese, it may have enough salt already. (And after you've tasted for salt, try not to keep "tasting," or before you know it half the potful is gone...! Yum!)
This was really really good! I didn't add any sugar ( because we are cutting back) and this soup was still delicious. I never knew what to do with an acorn squash.... This is it!

I always read the reviews on recipes before making them. I agree with cutting the sugar. Both times I have made it I used 1/4 cup unpacked brown sugar. I also added some sage and thyme to make it a little more savory.

I used vegan protein broth instead of chicken broth, and add a bit of dried parsley as it heated (since I didn't have fresh handy). It's totally different from any soup I've had before, but that's a good thing. - I would make again, but will need to cook the squash at least an hour.
Our family favorite!
I did not use the brown sugar. I did offer ground red pepper as an addition to anyone who wanted a kick, with the rich - sweet taste of this dish. Will be making this again.
This soup was very yummy and easy to make. I apparently like Rich and creamy, I put the full amount of cream cheese and sugar in and I love it!

Made it just as stated recipe except for also added some of the spices and rosemary olive oil to the squashes before baking them in the oven. It was AMAZING!! I’ve never made a squash soup before this. I think it tastes almost exactly like Panera’s Butternut Squash soup. I can’t stop eating it! Thanks for the recipe. (If I would have used less onion, I would have definitely used less brown sugar.)
Love this soup! I like adding some chopped red bell peppers when sautéing the onion.

This is a nice soup. I used half the called for cream cheese and 1/4 cup of brown sugar. I also added curry powder and nutmeg, as others have suggested. With all the seasoning, I just added "some" until I liked the taste. Pretty simple to put together.
I omitted the brown sugar and felt it was sweet enough without it. I also added just a touch of cayenne pepper for a little kick.

I didn’t have butternut squash so I used 2 acorn squash, which was likely why the color was not as vibrant as others I’ve seen. The flavor was amazing! We are not big on soups here, the kids rarely finish a bowl. Even my picky little ones devoured this soup! It is a sweet soup, but perfect for my sweet loving tastebuds.
could have been me, but it was a little bland. I added some salt, it helped a little. Overall it is a healthy good soup.

Reduced butter to 1Tbsp. Used only 4 oz of cream cheese, lower sodium chicken broth, 1/8 tsp of black pepper, pinch of chili powder and curry to taste. Left out the brown sugar. Very tasty with just a hint of spicy heat!
Delicious! I took advice of many and slightly reduced brown sugar and cream cheese. Sooo good!!

I love this soup. I roast the squash, use vegetable broth and I do not add cream cheese, butter or brown sugar to it. I add a lot of pepper and a lot more onion. I use olive oil instead of butter to make it vegan. I do not like dessert soup so I don't feel adding sugar to it is necessary, the squash is sweet enough on it's own.

WOW! Unbelievably good. Prepared exactly as written for the second time. Upscale restaurant quality. No kidding! Should definitely be called a bisque and not a soup. Yummmmm! 
Leah should win an award for this.
Delicious and so easy!
Added extra onion, but forgot to brown it first, will definitely brown need time. My wife liked it.
It was fantastic!

I cut the cream cheese down to 3/4 of a block and used about 3 tablespoons of brown erythritol to make it keto. Absolutely delicious! I've made it twice now -- once with a butternut and an acorn squash, and once with two butternuts. Wonderful both ways! And roast your squash seeds like pumpkin seeds -- they're delicious!
Soup was delicious. I used only 1 Tbsp of butter and olive oil, skipped the cream cheese and used honey instead of brown sugar. I also added nutmeg.

This was awesome! I doubled the recipe and took it to a gathering and everyone loved it. I put parsley and chives on the side for a garnish and both were very good with it. Many people asked for the recipe. Thank you! I will definitely make this again.
Super good recipe.
I substituted red onion, Thai coconut broth, goat cheese, and added sea salt, ginger and corn...so I guess I kind of sort of made it? :)

I've made this soup several times now since discovering this recipe. Based on other reviews, I only used a couple of spoonfuls of brown sugar and about a third of a block of cream cheese. I added cinnamon, nutmeg and a little ginger. The only instruction change I made was I peel the butternut squash first before baking....the skin is too soft for scooping the cooked squash. This soup is awesome and has been added to my list of must make soups.

This is one of my favorite fall soups. I followed advise from others and cut both the butter and the cream cheese in half. I add cayenne pepper to give it a little kick. I use a hand blender and blend right in the pot. Delicious!!
It was delicious!

Great soup. My husband adds sugar and fat (cheese, butter or sour cream) to everything, so the comments about this being sweet and rich hooked me. I made a couple changes. I didn't have any butternut squash, so I used two acorn squash and substituted half a can of pumpkin puree for color and depth of flavor. I kept the brown sugar and cream cheese just as directed. I added a pinch of ginger and two pinches of nutmeg in addition to the cinnamon. I also roasted my acorn squash with Garlic, cayenne pepper salt and black pepper. So this was sweet and creamy with a little kick. Very flavorful. I will definitely make this again.

I made it with vegetable broth instead of animal broth, and I only had about 5 oz of cream cheese in the fridge, so I subbed some sour cream in for the rest of it. Next time, I'll add the sour cream before I blend, little chunks in the pot didn't smooth out even over low heat. Should have known.

Really good though! I'm putting some in the fridge for the week, and freezing the rest!!
It turns out delicious every time I make it.
Great holiday soup!

I used butternut and acorn squash as well as leftover pumpkin from Thanksgiving. It was very rich - next time I’d go heavier on the chicken stock and lighter on the butter and cream cheese. Microwaving the squash is faster and easier than oven baking. A dash of pumpkin pie spice on top makes a nice garnish.
I am glad I read the reviews. I halved the butter, the sugar, and the cream cheese. I added a pinch of mace.
Wonderfully rich with a hint of sweetness!

Made as is, the only change I made is added sage infused butter and apple juice.
Great!

I used this as my initiation to my new pressure cooker. I just cut the squash in quarters (seeded) and popped it into my cooker (on the rack) with 1 1/2 c water, and cooked it on "steam" for 7 minutes. I vented when it was finished cooking, and the squash just fell off the skins. Then just continued with the recipie (adjusted for 4 servings) and it's fantastic!!!

I fully caramelized the onions for additional flavor and threw in several large dashes of hot sauce to give it a little spice to counteract the sweet. To garnish, I added roasted pumpkin seeds. Added a nice crunch.

I have made this soup many times. It is the best soup ever. I frequently double the squash when cooking and freeze half for a second batch, since cooking the squash is the most labor intensive part of the soup. Lots of times I cook the squash ahead of time when I have my oven on for something else. Let it cool, and remove skins. Then I refrigerate it and use it a day or two later for a quick meal. I only use 4 ounces of cream cheese and 2 Tablespoons of brown sugar. The acorn squash really ups the sweetness. especially when cooked until really soft.
I used real maple syrup instead of brown sugar because I was out. Loved it!

I followed other people's suggestion to 1/2 the cream cheese and use less sugar (I used about 1/6 of a cup. Soup was perfect! I had one butternut and one acorn squash hanging around and now they are gone!
Delicious! Much easier to make with an immersion blender.
great!
I used vegetable stock b/c that was what I had in the fridge and it was just as good ;)

I used shallots instead of onions and people raved about the taste. I used more water to make it thinner and added a pint of cream at the very end. So many people I didn't know at the party came to find me to tell me how much they loved this soup. Even my non-soup loving spouse loved it.
straight from the recipe, excellent taste, added a pinch of garlic powder

I didn't listen to the reviews and made it according to the recipe. It is a must to cut the cream cheese and brown sugar down. it is so so so sweet and rich. cut down on that and add a little curry powder and a spicy spice (cayenne pepper) and ur good to go!!!

Used coconut milk instead of cream cheese since I had some I wanted to use up and sautéed one sliced apple with the onion. Also added a little garlic powder. Used little less brown sugar as week per others recommendations
I used dried onion powder instead of fresh onions. Tastes great!
Hi my name is Olivia I'm 7 years old I thought it was great but it was so sweet and it tasted like a potato the tesure was not thick.and it looked nothing like the picture.
This is fantastic! I didn't change a thing and I love it.
I used 1/4 cup sugar. It was delicious! May try with even less next time.
I dont know why but mine came out really blan :( I was not that impressed with this recipe.
Recipe was too sweet for my tastes. Needed just a little more cream cheese and less brown sugar. Other than that, it is yummy.

I substituted a vegetable stock of carrots, celery, onion, and salt and omitted the cream cheese. Not listed, but absolutely essential to a full flavor, I added 1 tsp of salt, though it could have used even more. I may cut back on the sugar a bit next time, but otherwise, a wonderful start.
Loved it!
My favorite fall and winter soup!

Yes, I substituted Cayenne vs. black pepper; I added 1 cup cooked brown rice; I substituted plain yogurt vs. 8 oz. cream cheese; I substituted coconut sugar for the brown sugar; I added 1/2 teaspoon ground Ginger for more zest and, I did not puree all the squash as we prefer more texture. My son liked it and asked for more!

This was a huge hit in my house! I did reduce the sugar and cream cheese as recommended (by about 1/3), and it turned out so incredibly well. I had to cook the squash quite a bit longer initially than was recommended by the recipe to make sure it was soft enough to put in the blender. Will definitely be making this again!

I had a butternut, acorn, and winter squash in the pantry. Since I had a bit more squash than the recipe called for, I used 1/4c brown sugar, but I think I could have left it at 1/3c as it was still quite sweet. Again, having extra squash, I didn't add any extra broth, and I really liked the consistency as it was. Couldn't have made this without my Ninja mixer. I think it's time I get a food processor, as I definitely plan to make this often.
I used half the cream cheese and it is still very thick, will need to add more chicken stock when I reheat it.

This is a delicious soup, but I made several changes, just like the other reviewers. I omitted the brown sugar altogether, and doubled the chicken stock. I added a carrot and some celery with the onion, along with a few garlic cloves. I also used a spaghetti, rather than an acorn, squash. I used about 4oz of goat cheese (it was what I had on hand), rather than the cream cheese. Some cayenne and curry powder for a nice, savory finish. Delicious!
Delicious! I halved the amount of cream cheese and butter at the advice of others. The family's comments said it all..."we can have this again ANYTIME"

Followed the recipe but incorporated some of the suggestions. I cut back by about 1/3 on the cream cheese and used a light touch with nutmeg and cinnamon, tasting as I went. The soup was a great hit on Thanksgiving. Delicious. I will definitely make this again!

This was easy and delicious, especially since I had roasted both the acorn and butternut squash yesterday. I had all other ingredients on hand. The food processor was a great asset in pureeing the ingredients. Thanks for a yummy soup!
like with a sandwich. we like using a hand mixer to blend it because it leaves chucks of squash

I absolutely loved it! I made this for my kids and myself plus I shared it with my parents the next day. They all love this soup! I'll be making it again tomorrow for a soup sale we're having in my community!

I made this recipe just as written and it came out very good.
Next time I will do as others suggested and add the brown sugar at the end, 1 Tbsp. at a time. The squash itself lends a lot of sweetness to the soup.
I served this with toasted sourdough bread.

Not a huge fan of squash, but I gave this a try. It was delicious! I used light brown sugar, added the cinnamon and a pinch of salt. It was rich, but well balanced. I didn't find it overly sweet. Will be making this again!

Sauteed the onions but then forgot to puree them with the rest of everything. Used just water, not broth, mainly because I wanted it to be vegetarian, and it turned out great. I've had other friends make this and rave about it. Made it once before with turkey stock and it tasted just like the holidays.
excellent
this was vey easy to make and was simply delicious!!
